text: you
of course art has always been used to
help
we'll deal with things that are
literally almost impossible to see and
that's the case with 911 as well right
after the attacks on the world trade
center I went out and walked around my
neighborhood with an old bollocks and
documented storefronts streets different
parts of my neighborhood in East
Williamsburg not as an art project but
simply because I felt like it needed to
be documented the response was so
intense both in terms of just surging
patriotism that that you know the walls
of flags but also creatively the way my
neighbors were implementing their own
expression you know the the kind of
storefronts and windows of homes were
all full of makeshift memorials and
commemorations ranging from crayon
hand-drawn flags to really installations
I forgot about that footage and just put
it away and near the end of the decade
right before Obama got elected I was
really trying to think about the now and
what we had just gone through over this
decade and I remembered the footage and
decided to try and find the locations
and went and reshot it all the same
framing compositions camera time of day
day of the year and the piece juxtaposes
next to each other those two time
periods New Yorkers relationship to each
other I think I think has always been
really special and I think there's
nobody that couldn't relate to the
profound in beautiful ways that New
Yorker is supported each other after 911
and I do think that that while it's
watered down perhaps has stayed it's a
hard thing I think the people are scared
in ways that they don't even realize
that there's a kind of psychological
unconscious way that were living
with the wreckage of that historical
time period that I really think it will
take a long time for us to understand
how it's changed does there is a
photograph that was published in The
Times Magazine very soon after the
attacks we're worse the camera is
situated in the East Williamsburg
looking at rooftops and you can see the
towers all the smoke of the collapsed
hours and I've had that on my bulletin
board for a decade and I think you know
now those towers are down and in terms
of my own practice it almost doesn't
matter that they've been extracted from
that picture there just still there and
a consciousness of that I don't see that
there's any way that anything i do will
ever not have that in my work
